title: 113_hr3669
content: The Act titled "Federal Probation System Reform Act" establishes regulations for electronic monitoring devices in Chapter 239 of Title 18 of the United States Code. The Act "Federal Probation System Reform Act" in Chapter 239 of Title 18 of the United States Code mandates supervision of individuals wearing electronic monitoring devices as a condition of release. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts oversees this requirement for those on probation, supervised release, or pending trial for a Federal offense. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts ensures that probation or pretrial services officers supervise individuals wearing electronic monitoring devices by conducting daily reviews of data and investigating alerts immediately. Uniform standards must be issued within 60 days to implement this requirement. Penalty for disabling an electronic monitoring device: Whoever intentionally disables or allows another person to disable an electronic monitoring device assigned as a condition of probation, supervised release, or release pending trial shall be punished accordingly. The punishment for disabling an electronic monitoring device includes a fine or imprisonment for up to 4 years if the person commits a crime in addition to disabling the device, and a fine or imprisonment for up to 1 year if no additional crime is committed. SEC. 3. INSPECTOR GENERAL FOR PROBATION AND PRETRIAL SERVICES. The Office of the Inspector General for Probation and Pretrial Services is established within the United States Probation and Pretrial Services System. The Inspector General is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States after consultation with Senate and House leaders. The Inspector General for Probation and Pretrial Services is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States for a four-year term, with the possibility of reappointment. The Inspector General can be removed by the Chief Justice, who must provide reasons to Congress. The Office's duties include investigating misconduct, conducting audits, preventing fraud, and recommending changes in laws. The Inspector General has the power to conduct investigations, obtain information from various agencies, and compel witnesses to testify or produce documents through subpoena enforcement. The Inspector General has the authority to enforce actions through civil means, administer oaths, hire staff under specific regulations, procure services at specified rates, and access funds as approved by appropriations Acts. The Inspector General is authorized to enter into contracts for audits and services, with limitations on investigating judicial decisions or disciplining officers. Annual reports are required to be made to the Director. The Inspector General is required to make annual reports to the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and Congress, as well as prompt reports on matters requiring action. If a report contains sensitive information, it may be received in closed session by Congress. The Inspector General must report promptly to the Attorney General if there are reasonable grounds to believe a violation of Federal criminal law has occurred. Whistleblower protection is provided, ensuring no repercussions for reporting violations. No officer, employee, agent, contractor, or subcontractor of pretrial services may discriminate against an employee for providing information on violations of Federal law or regulations. In case of violation, the injured employee can seek relief through a civil action. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of these measures. Chapter 207 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to update section 3157(b) and the table of sections. The text chunk "3155. Inspector General for Probation and Pretrial Services." is a part of the amendment to Chapter 207 of title 18, United States Code, which updates section 3157(b) and the table of sections.
